## Buyers Guide

Last Updated: November 07, 2023

It’s not easy running a child care center. Even after administrators have met
licensing requirements, determined a legal structure, found the perfect
location and hired staff, they still have to handle a variety of daily tasks
to keep kids (and their parents) happy.

Child care software helps users manage the day-to-day aspects of running a
daycare center or preschool. Among other things, these systems can automate
administrative tasks, keep attendance records, store parents’ contact
information, track children’s health data and help users schedule classes and
appointments.

This guide can help potential buyers find the best solution for their needs.
Here’s what we’ll cover:

What Is Child Care Software?

Common Functionality of Child Care Software

Benefits of Child Care Management Software

Pricing: Web-Based vs. On-Premise

Industry Trends

## What Is Child Care Software?

Child care professionals are busy, and it can be difficult for them to not
only keep up with their young charges, but stay on top of administrative,
scheduling and financial duties, as well. That’s where child care management
software comes in: It helps child care workers simplify and streamline the
manual processes they do every day, including recordkeeping, billing,
attendance and immunization tracking.

Child care management software is also known as “child care administrative
software” or “daycare management software.” The technology is useful for all
kinds of child care centers, including:

  * Day-care centers

  * Licensed family child care homes

  * Early childhood education programs/preschools

  * After-school programs

  * Drop-in programs

Once an organization is ready to open its doors to potential clients, it’s
never too early to invest in a software system. Doing so can ensure they’re
organized from the start and set up for success.

For example, some center administrators think a single-application software,
such as an accounting program from an industry-agnostic vendor, will be enough
to fulfill their needs. However, that isn’t ideal for long-term growth. It’s
usually better to get a dedicated child care management solution because it
lets you streamline every aspect of the business, eliminating the need to buy
different applications from multiple vendors that don’t interface with one
another.

## Common Functionality of Child Care Management Software

Most child care management systems will come with some or all of the following
capabilities:

 **Admissions and scheduling**

|

Provides widgets and calendars for scheduling classes as well as enrollment
and registration.  
  
---|---  
  
 **Billing and payments**

|

Allows users to perform billing and invoicing, track account balances and
past-due payments, create and print payment reports and statements and post
payment in batches. Offers support for multiple online and in-person payment
methods, including cash, check, money order and credit cards.  
  
 **Immunization tracking**

|

Tracks and stores children’s immunization records, including past, current and
completed vaccinations and immunization due dates.  
  
 **Reporting**

|

Generates reports of and provides alerts for children’s birthdays. Also
creates reports on revenue summaries, class statistics (e.g., class type and
size), attendance and financial transactions.  
  
 **Employee management/time and attendance**

|

Facilitates staff check-in and check-out; manages employee hours; stores pay
rates and other staffing information at organization-wide and location-
specific levels.  
  
 **Communication**

|

Allows users to keep parents informed about their child’s activities via
mobile application alerts, emails or text messages.  
  
 **Meal management**

|

Some systems offer menu planning, meal tracking and nutrition analysis
functionality.  
  
 **Activity planning**

|

Enables staff to create lesson plans or activity plans in advance.  
  
## Benefits of Child Care Management Software

Daycare and preschool facilities can realize many benefits as a result of
adopting child care management software, including:

 **Less administrative work.** Generally, staff in a daycare or preschool
facility handles both administrative and physical child care duties. This
software automates administrative tasks, such as online registration, so
employees can focus their energy on the children themselves.

 **Improved communication with parents.** Working parents don’t need to worry
or inquire about their children. With child care management software, your
facility can send parents notifications about their child throughout the day
via native mobile apps or text messaging.

 **Advanced meal and nutrition planning.** Some vendors offer tools for
tracking the number of provided meals, as well as for planning breakfast,
lunch and snacks based on the nutritional requirements of each child. With
this functionality, child care centers can give growing kids the nourishment
they need.

 **Greater staff coordination.** As opposed to paper-based records, digital
systems are accessible to multiple users in separate locations. This makes it
easier for employees to update any necessary documentation and for the
business to scale.

## Pricing: Cloud-Based vs. On-Premise

There are two main pricing models prevalent in this market. Select the one
that best fits your budget and business model:

Cloud-based **software.** These solutions are typically priced on a monthly or
an annual subscription basis. They require low or no upfront investment, and
vendors handle system maintenance and updates. This option is often best for
small and midsize businesses that may not have the resources to invest in and
manage an on-premise system.

 **On-premise software.** These systems typically require purchasing a
perpetual license for a substantial upfront fee. There are no recurring
license fees, but extra fees may apply for implementation assistance,
maintenance, support and updates.

No matter which system you choose, over a period of time, pricing for these
two models tends to converge.

## Industry Trends

 **Mobile device integration.** Systems are starting to introduce native apps
for mobile devices that can be used for administrative purposes or to connect
with parents. For example, some apps may allow you to track child arrivals and
departures by asking parents to check in and out of your center with a tablet
placed near the entrance. On the other hand, some apps are meant to be
downloaded by parents and can be used as a platform to exchange pictures and
messages about their children with your staff.

 **Staff training and development.** If you want to attract and retain great
employees, you may want to consider offering them professional development
opportunities, such as enrolling them in online child care courses. Software
can help you keep track of which staff members have completed training
programs and received certifications.
